The White Tower Exhibition presents Thessaloniki's history through multimedia and is organized into seven thematic categories across different floors. Additionally, the Jewish Museum of Thessaloniki promotes Sephardic legacy and features a research center, library, and audiovisual center. Its permanent exhibitions cover topics such as the Jewish necropolis and the history of the Jewish community in Thessaloniki up to World War II.", "Thessaloniki is renowned for its vibrant nightlife, often considered Greece's entertainment capital. The city offers a variety of options including avant-garde bars, tavernas, ouzo restaurants, and modern cuisine spots. Popular nightlife areas include Ladadika, Kalapothaki Street, and the beachfront cafés. Students frequent Navarinou square, Rotonda, and Bit-Pazar, while Ano Poli features alternative tavernas and café-bars. Recently, Valaoritou Street has emerged as a nightlife hotspot, especially in summer. The Slaughterhouse area hosts large venues for live Greek music and the biggest clubs in the city.", "The text describes various locations and landmarks in Thessaloniki, including the historic center, the White Tower area, and notable streets. The historic center is recognized for its proximity to the beach and is a residential area for the affluent, featuring shops, green spaces, and cultural institutions. The White Tower is highlighted as the city's most famous landmark, built in the late 15th century, and serves as a significant historical monument. It stands 33.90 meters high and has a diameter of 22.70 meters, originally surrounded by fortifications. The area around the White Tower is a central hub where major roads converge, offering views of the sea and a vibrant atmosphere with shops and cafés.", 'The International Book Fair in Thessaloniki is an annual event held in the HELEXPO-TIF exhibition center, attracting professionals and book lovers. It features presentations from Greek and foreign publishers, discussions with writers, and various themed corners for children and teenagers. The Society for Macedonian Studies is a key cultural institution in Thessaloniki, focusing on the preservation and promotion of Macedonian history and culture. The National Theatre of Northern Greece, established in 1961, is the largest cultural organization in northern Greece, hosting various performances across multiple venues. Thessaloniki also offers a range of indoor and outdoor theatre stages, providing diverse entertainment options throughout the year.', 'The text describes various historical and archaeological sites in the region, including the Praetorium, public toilets, and the Hydraulis sector known for its copper items. It highlights the Villa of Dionysus, famous for its mosaic of Dionysus. The Archaeological Museum showcases artifacts from the Dion area and nearby ancient sites. Mt. Olympus, the highest mountain in Greece, is noted for its biodiversity and as a popular destination for hiking. Ancient Pydna, once an administrative center under Macedon, faced decline after Roman conquest and was eventually deserted.', 'The Greek National Tourism Organisation promotes tourism in Greece through its website, www.visitgreece.gr.', 'The 6th walk in Thessaloniki highlights several must-see landmarks along NEA PARALIA and VASILISSIS OLGAS AVENUE. Key attractions include the Monument of Alexander the Great, a large equestrian statue near the White Tower, and the statue of politician Konstantinos Karamanlis. The Makedonia Palace Hotel, a luxury accommodation, is noted for its historical significance and frequent patronage by political figures. The Umbrellas sculpture by George Zongolopoulos, a prominent art piece, is also featured, along with the Agioi Kyrillos and Methodios Church, dedicated to the saints who spread Christianity to the Slavs.', 'Ano Poli, an area of 3,000 hectares, features a small remnant of an old oak forest and has undergone reforestation since the 1930s. It remains a popular destination for outdoor activities like hiking and mountain biking, despite urban expansion and a significant fire in 1997. Key attractions include the Zoo, which houses various Greek wildlife, the Forest Theatre for summer concerts, and the Theatre of the Earth, a notable cultural venue. Visitors can access these sites via bus no. 24 from Eleftherias square. The nearby Sykees area retains its charm with Interwar Period houses amidst modern development.', 'The area includes historical sites such as the former Turkish army barracks and the War Museum, designed by V. Poselli. It also features the Papafeio Orphanage, a classical style building completed in 1903, which served various purposes including a male boarding school and military barracks. Nearby, the YFANET textile factory was once a major textile unit in Macedonia and is now a venue for events and a library. Additionally, visitors can explore a rare Macedonian tomb from the 3rd century BC and the neoclassical Ippokrateio Hospital built in 1891.', 'The text describes various museums in Macedonia, including sections on antiquities from the 2nd to 4th centuries AD, prehistoric items, and temporary exhibitions. The Roman Forum Museum, inaugurated in 2010, showcases local excavations and historical artifacts from the Hellenistic period to the 4th century AD, including a bathhouse and ancient brothel. The Museum of Byzantine Culture is highlighted as one of the best in Greece, featuring 2,900 exhibits that include murals, mosaics, icons, and everyday tools, providing a comprehensive view of Byzantine culture.', 'The 7th walk in Stavroupoli highlights notable cultural venues like Mylos, a former flour mill turned multi-purpose venue, and FIX Brewery, founded in 1893 and now mostly deserted except for concert halls. The Terpsithea District features well-planned urban spaces, including the old military camp and Lebet mosque, which will be transformed into a park. The Jewish cemetery, established in 1938, contains remnants from a previous cemetery destroyed during WWII. A must-see is the Allied Military Cemetery, the largest in Greece, housing over 21,000 soldiers from World War I. Additionally, the Moni Lazariston, built in 1886 by Lazarist monks, is an impressive historical site.', "The text describes various streets and locations in Thessaloniki, highlighting their historical significance and current status. Dimokratias Square is noted as a key entry point to the city, serving as a transportation hub with hotels, shops, and a statue of King Constantine. The surrounding area features mostly unremarkable buildings but also historic sites, including sections of the city's west walls and archaeological monuments. The Railway Station, located on Monastiriou Street, is mentioned as a significant structure that began construction in 1939 and became operational in 1951.", "The historic centre features the White Tower, originally known as the Tower of the Janissaries, which served as a jail and now hosts exhibitions on Thessaloniki's history. Visitors can enjoy panoramic views from the top and relax in the surrounding square, which is a hotspot for boat bars. The Royal Theatre, built in 1940 and renovated in 1996, has a capacity of 800 and is part of the State Theatre of Northern Greece. Ethnikis Amynis Street connects the White Tower to Syntrivaniou Square and was established after the demolition of city walls in 1889. Previously named Hamidiye Boulevard, it is now home to various cultural institutions, including the Theatre of the Society for Macedonian Studies and popular cafés and bars nearby.", 'The text describes various historical sites in a town, including Main Street, which was lined with shops and public buildings. The Great Thermae was a large public bath complex featuring marble floors and areas for worship and entertainment. The Houses of Zosa and Lida were decorated with mosaics and sculptures. The Roman Forum, dating back to the late 2nd to early 3rd century, included luxury houses and a temple for emperor worship. A polygonal building served as a roofed marketplace, while remnants of Early Christian Walls were found nearby. An episcopal basilica was rebuilt in the 5th century after its destruction in the 4th century. The Praetorium functioned as an inn for officials and travelers, with access to the Main Street Thermae. Additionally, the text mentions a climbing route in Olympus National Park and the Petralona Museum, showcasing prehistoric human activity.', 'The Agora, a 4th century BC building complex, served as the administrative and cultural hub of the town, featuring a large court and various commercial shops. Excavations have revealed several temples, including those dedicated to the Mother of Gods and Aphrodite. The Palace, located on a northern hill, dates back to the 4th century BC and includes a peristyle and royal quarters. The Eastern cemetery contains rock-hewn cist graves from the Copper Age to Classical times. The Alexander the Great Bathhouse, a Hellenistic facility, is also notable. The Archaeological Museum showcases five thematic categories, including daily life, public life, religious practices, cemetery finds, and the architectural design of the palace, along with information about Alexander the Great.', "The text describes various museums, including the Water Museum, which features restored buildings showcasing pumping machinery and historical archives. The Children's Museum, targeting ages 4-12, offers educational programs and is currently located in Thessaloniki's Cultural Centre after a fire destroyed its previous location. The Noesis Science Centre and Technology Museum includes exhibitions on Ancient Greek technology and interactive exhibits on electricity and magnetism.", "The 5th walk in Ano Poli (Old Town) connects Agios Pavlos area and Agiou Dimitriou Street, offering views of the city's eastern walls. The Gardens of the Pasha, built in 1904, feature eccentric architecture and an art nouveau fountain. Agios Pavlos church, named after a fountain where Apostle Paul drank, is located nearby. Agios Dimitrios Hospital, built around 1902-3, showcases classicist and baroque styles and is a listed monument. Evangelistria Cemetery, established in 1875, is the city's oldest Christian cemetery, housing notable figures. Nearby are the Armenian and Protestant cemeteries and a historic foundry now used for cultural events.", "The text describes several significant Byzantine monuments in the Ano Poli area, including the 14th-century Agia Aikaterini Church, known for its elaborate brickwork and murals depicting saints and Gospel scenes. It was converted into a mosque during Ottoman rule but restored between 1947 and 1951. The Profitis Ilias Church, dating from the late 13th to mid-14th century, is noted for its architectural features and murals of Christ's life. Additionally, the Byzantine Baths, a 13th-century domed structure, is the only surviving bathhouse from that era, which was open to the public until 1940.", 'The text describes various locations in Ano Poli, Thessaloniki, including the historical significance of the eastern walls and the neoclassical G. Gennimatas hospital. It mentions Kallitheas Square, a picturesque area with a playground, and major streets leading out of the city walls. Additionally, it references the Seich Sou forest, the largest forested area near the city.', '', 'The text describes various historical buildings along Vas. Olgas Avenue in Thessaloniki, including the Folklife and Ethnological Museum of Macedonia – Thrace, which was once a residence of banker Jacob Modiano. Other notable buildings include a former private residence that now serves as a nursery school, the Melissa Building which housed an orphanage and now hosts the Centre for Byzantine Research, and the School for the Blind, originally built as a private residence. The Jeborga Villa, once the Italian Consulate, is now deserted. The Yeni Mosque and Modiano Villa are also mentioned for their eclectic architectural features.', 'Chortiatis is a small suburb located on Mt. Chortiatis, known for its hiking trails and historical significance, including remnants of a Byzantine aqueduct. Thermi, situated 15 km southeast of Thessaloniki, retains a countryside feel and was historically significant as the harbor of ancient Thermi, famous for its hot springs. The central square of Thermi, Paramana Square, is noted for its futuristic design and serves as a hub for local businesses. An artificial lake nearby offers recreational opportunities and hosts the Dam Music Festival in summer, while the Environmental Park provides various sports facilities.', "Aristotelous Square in Thessaloniki is one of Greece's largest and most vibrant squares, operational 24/7. It was part of the Hébrard Committee's urban plan post-1917 fire, fully realized by the early 1960s. The square offers stunning views of the Thermaic Gulf and Olympus massif, featuring monumental architecture that blends Byzantine and European interwar styles. Key landmarks include the Electra Palace hotel and Olympion, the latter hosting the Thessaloniki Film Festival. Aristotelous Street, a pedestrianized historic boulevard, connects to Egnatia Street.", 'The text describes various historical sites in Thessaloniki, including the Hippodrome, which was a center of social activity until 390 AD when a massacre led to its closure. It highlights the Thessaloniki History Centre and the 18th-century Agios Antonios church nearby. The Arched Hall, located at the intersection of Gounari and Svolou streets, was used for symposia and had access to the imperial box in the Hippodrome. Additionally, remnants of a theatre-stadium on Apellou Street date back to the 1st to 4th centuries AD and are linked to the martyrdom of Agios Dimitrios. The text also mentions three notable churches on Egnatia Street, including the Panagouda Church, built in 1818 on the site of an older church destroyed by fire. The area is rich in history and cultural significance, making it a must-visit for tourists.', 'The number 116 is repeated twice.', 'The map of Thessaloniki highlights various public agencies and services, including the G.N.T.O. Information Office, Ministry of Macedonia – Thrace, and the Police Department. It also features significant Roman monuments such as the Roman Forum and the Arch of Galerius, alongside Byzantine churches like Agia Sofia and Agios Dimitrios. Ottoman monuments are represented by the White Tower and various hamams. Additionally, the map includes 19th to 20th-century landmarks like Aristotelous Square and the YMCA of Thessaloniki.', "The text describes several significant Byzantine monuments, including their architectural features and historical transformations. The first is a tetrastyle cross-in-square church that became a mosque, obscuring its original murals. The Panagia Chalkeon Church, built in 1128, showcases the 'School of Constantinople' architecture and was also converted into a mosque. Acheiropoietos Church, founded in the 5th century, features a three-aisled basilica and was the first church turned into a mosque after the Turkish conquest. Lastly, Agia Sofia Church, built in the mid-7th century, is a replica of the Hagia Sophia in Constantinople, highlighting its historical significance.", 'The historic center of Thessaloniki features a shopping mall that was reshaped between 1995-1997, retaining its original exterior while now housing shops, cinemas, cafés, and restaurants around a central atrium. Notable buildings from the early 20th century are located at the junction of Tsimiski and Karolou Dil Streets, currently serving as shops and offices. The traditional market area, west of Aristotelous Street and south of Egnatia Street, is filled with small shops, malls, and arcades dating back to the Turkish Occupation, offering a variety of products including food, spices, and fabrics. Modiano Market, built in 1922, is a prominent glass-roofed structure with 140 food shops and popular restaurants. The Vlali-Kapani and Athonos-Vatikioti Markets, designed by Ernest Hébrard, feature two-storeyed malls with archways and are connected to Aristotelous Street.', 'The text describes notable buildings in the historic center of Thessaloniki, including the YMCA Building, which features a mix of neo-colonial and Byzantine architecture and houses various sports and cultural facilities. The Archaeological Museum, designed by P. Karantinos and inaugurated in 1962, showcases modernist architectural design and includes spaces for exhibitions and events. The Museum of Byzantine Culture, built between 1989 and 1993, combines modernism with Greek tradition and is recognized as a historic monument. It contains an amphitheater, a café-restaurant, and exhibition spaces, alongside the new Town Hall and a park.', 'Ano Poli, or Old Town, was established to house early 20th-century refugees, with historical settlements dating back to the 2nd century AD. The area features the Municipal Grove with a theatre for summer cultural events and an open-air cinema. A prominent church, Agioi Theodoroi, built on a 7th-century Byzantine site, offers stunning city views. Nearby, Elpidos Street has refugee houses being transformed into a Cultural Neighbourhood. Access to Sykees is available by walking from Ano Poli or taking bus no. 23 to Agios Charalampos stop.', 'The text describes various day excursions near Ancient Pella, including Aravissou springs, Platanopotamos Lake, and Dytiko plane-tree forest. It provides directions to Ancient Pella from Thessaloniki and mentions the military Museum of Balkan Wars. Additionally, it highlights the historical significance of Vergina (Aiges), the former capital of Macedon, detailing its importance from the 10th-8th century BC until its destruction by the Romans in 168 BC. The archaeological site is recognized as a UNESCO World Heritage Site, featuring the Royal Tombs discovered by archaeologist Manolis Andronikos in 1977.', 'The text describes a walking tour along Vasilissis Olgas Avenue, highlighting historical buildings and residences. Notable sites include the Hirsch villa, a former police department, and the Chatzilazarou Residence, built in 1890. The Marokou Residence, previously a boarding school, now houses a Traffic Police Department. The Mehmet Kapanci Villa, constructed in 1893, served various significant roles, including housing military leaders and high schools, and is now part of the Thessaloniki Cultural Centre. The Ahmet Kapanci Villa, built in 1905, features eclectic architectural styles and has housed various organizations over the years, including the Red Cross and NATO services.', "The Historic Centre features Plateia Dikastirion, a green square where the Court House was planned but halted due to the discovery of the Ancient Roman Forum. The square has a bust of Eleftherios Venizelos, a significant Greek prime minister. Nearby, the Bey Hamami, built in 1444, is the largest Ottoman bathhouse in Greece, known as the Paradise Baths until 1968. The Roman Forum, a 2-hectare area, served as the city's social and religious center during the Roman period, with construction completed in the mid-2nd to mid-3rd centuries AD. The site includes a large square with traces of marble paving and a double underground Cryptoporticus, likely used as a public storehouse, featuring an early Christian mural.", "The text describes various historical and architectural landmarks in Thessaloniki, including the West of the Centre-Stavroupoli inaugurated in 1962, which connects the city to Greece and the Balkans. The Old Railway Station, built in 1894, is now a cargo station and was historically significant during the German occupation. The Top Hane (Vardariou Tower), constructed by the Ottomans in 1546, served as a city stronghold and remains well-preserved. The De La Salle Complex, built in 1926, now houses the city's Administrative Courts, while the Vienni Hotel, established in 1925, reflects the eclectic architectural trends of its time and currently contains private offices.", 'Noesis is a unique science center and technology museum in Greece, completed in 2004, featuring exhibitions, a digital library, and an amphitheater. It can be accessed via public transport or car from Thessaloniki. The seaside areas of Peraia, Neoi Epivates, and Agia Triada, located 20 km from the city center, were settled by refugees in 1923 and have since developed into popular suburbs and resorts with Blue Flag beaches and various amenities. Buses connect these areas to the city, providing easy access for visitors.', 'The text describes various attractions in Thessaloniki, including the historic center, shopping streets, and museums. It highlights the eclectic-style building housing the local Greek Scouts and the upscale shopping areas with boutiques and art galleries. The Museum for the Macedonian Struggle, a neo-classical building, is noted for its historical significance and previous functions. Nearby, the metropolitan church of Agios Gregorios Palamas showcases Byzantine architecture, and the Ecclesiastical Museum offers a collection related to the church.', "Dion, located 87 km SW of Thessaloniki, features a significant neolithic settlement, early-Christian basilicas, and a 10th-century basilica with impressive mosaics. Visitors can reach Dion via national roads or local buses from Katerini. The Petralona Cave, discovered in 1959, is notable for its prehistoric findings, including a 200,000-400,000-year-old skull, making it one of Europe's oldest archaeological sites. The cave showcases various prehistoric items and is partially open to visitors. Halkidiki, known for its beautiful beaches and rich history, is a popular tourist destination south of Thessaloniki, featuring three peninsulas: Kassandra, Sithonia, and Athos.", 'The museum features a collection of over 2,500 corkscrews from the 16th to 20th centuries, categorized by mechanical and non-mechanical types, as well as by gender usage. It includes explanatory texts and photographs. Additionally, touch screens display a glossary of viticulture and wine-making terms. Room B showcases the historical significance of wine through tools and vessels, along with scenes from films and photos related to wine production and consumption.', "The text describes significant Byzantine monuments in Thessaloniki, including the UNESCO-listed church that was once a cathedral and later converted into a mosque, showcasing impressive mosaics and murals. It also highlights the Transfiguration of the Saviour Church, a typical example of Byzantine architecture from around 1340, adorned with depictions of Christ's Ascension. Additionally, the Rotunda, built in 306 AD, is noted for its massive dome and preserved mosaics, which were later converted into a mosque. The surrounding area includes the small church of Agios Georgios, further enriching the historical context of these monuments.", "Thessaloniki, founded in the 4th century BC, has maintained its urban character as a civic center influenced by various empires and multicultural groups. Its rich history includes Roman, Byzantine, and Ottoman rule, with contributions from Jews, Latins, Armenians, and Greeks. The city's numerous historical monuments reflect its cosmopolitan nature. The White Tower area is a bustling part of Thessaloniki, where the old seafront meets the new waterfront.", 'The text describes various historical and cultural sites in Thessaloniki, including the impressive complex of 14 listed industrial buildings from 1854, originally owned by the French and later by the Allatini family. It mentions the Vafopouleio Cultural Centre, inaugurated in 1983, which hosts art exhibitions, performances, and has three libraries. The Ouziel quarter features picturesque semi-detached houses built for tramway workers, now a protected architectural monument. Sofouli Street connects eastern districts with Kalamaria, lined with trees, shops, and offering views of the city. Vasilissis Olgas Avenue, once a favorite promenade, is noted for its green surroundings along the waterfront.', "Thessaloniki offers various outdoor activities such as hiking and mountain biking in the suburban forests of Seich Sou and Chortiatis, as well as relaxing by the Deltas of Gallikos and Axios-Loudias-Aliakmonas rivers. Educational programs for children are available in most museums, particularly at the unique Children's Museum. The Noesis Science Centre and Technology Museum provides fun and educational experiences related to science and technology. Visitors can also explore the Environmental Dinosaur Theme Park and the Mammoth Museum. For beach lovers, there are beautiful seaside options in Thessaloniki and Halkidiki. Families can enjoy the Magic Park, Greece's largest amusement park, and WaterLand, which features various water attractions.", 'The text describes various historical and cultural sites in a city, focusing on Agia Sofia Square, which features greenery and is shaped by the 1890 fire. It highlights the pedestrianized Agias Sofias Street, notable buildings like the Longos Building and Chatzidimitriou Building, and the monument commemorating the Genocide of Pontic Greeks. Navarinou Square is presented as a vibrant student area with cafés, bars, and cultural venues, along with a fountain and playground. The area also includes shops selling books, records, and antiques, and encourages visits to the nearby church of Nea Panagia, dating back to 1727.', 'The text describes day excursions from Thessaloniki, highlighting the monastic state of Mount Athos, which features 20 inhabited monasteries and is a UNESCO World Heritage site. It provides directions to Petralona Cave, located 53 km southeast of Thessaloniki, accessible by coach and taxi or by car. Additionally, it mentions the Lakes Area northeast of Thessaloniki, a National Park with diverse ecosystems ideal for outdoor activities. The area is managed by an agency that offers tours, and visitors are encouraged to try local fish dishes. Lastly, it notes the town of Lagadas, known for its fire-walking custom and modern spa facilities with historical Byzantine bathtubs.', 'The text describes two museums: Noesis and Gerovassiliou Wine Museum. Noesis focuses on interactive learning with exhibits like a car exhibition, a planetarium, a cosmotheatre, and a virtual reality simulator. It also offers educational programs on renewable energy and science. The Gerovassiliou Wine Museum, established in 2008, showcases the history of wine-making and features collections that illustrate the journey of wine, food pairings, and wine-making equipment. Both museums emphasize visitor engagement and education.', 'Thessaloniki offers various tourism services including an Info Point at Aristotelous Square, open Mon-Fri from 9 am to 5 pm. The Thessaloniki Tourism Organisation provides information and assistance, reachable at 2310 279.282 or via email at welcome@thessaloniki.travel. The Tourist Police, available at 1571, assists tourists with information and minor disputes. The city has over 130 hotels with a capacity of approximately 13,000 beds, and inquiries can be made through the Thessaloniki Hotels Association. For conferences, the Thessaloniki Convention Bureau can be contacted for well-equipped venues. Organized excursions can be arranged through local travel agencies, and car rental services are available through the Car Rental Agencies Association. Yacht charters can be organized via the Hellenic Yacht Brokers Association.', 'The text describes the historical and cultural significance of suburbs and outskirts of Thessaloniki, including ancient tombs and a Neolithic settlement. It provides directions to Kalochori via bus or car. Kalamaria, a prominent suburb, features green spaces and a shopping center, with a history of Greek refugees settling there in the 1920s. Key sites include Sofouli Street, the Little Palace (formerly a royal residence), and the Kodra former military camp, which is being transformed into a park. Excavations in Kodra revealed an ancient settlement, possibly linked to Ancient Thermi.', "The Museum of Greek Children’s Art showcases the creativity of children, depicting Greek history, tradition, and culture through their artwork. It is one of the few museums worldwide dedicated to children's art.", "Egnatia Street is a historic avenue in Thessaloniki, dating back to Roman times, connecting Dyrrhachium and Constantinople. It runs from Dimokratia Square to the TIF grounds and the Aristotle University, serving as a bustling shopping area with notable eclectic and art deco buildings. Key attractions include Kolomvou Square, a lively hub with cafés and bars, and the Hamza Bey Mosque, built in 1467, which is currently undergoing renovations for an exhibition. The street splits the city's historic center and features important monuments worth observing.", "The text describes various cultural and historical sites in Thessaloniki, including a small museum dedicated to the founder of modern Turkey, the Teloglion Foundation of Art with its modern facilities, and the Kaftanzogleio Stadium, which was the largest in Greece until 1982 and is home to the city's oldest football team, Iraklis. The stadium also hosted events during the 2004 Athens Olympic Games and is near the Olympic Museum.", 'The area along NEA PARALIA features 12 Theme Gardens covering 76,657 m2, ideal for leisure activities. Notable gardens include the Garden of Alexander, Garden of the Seasons with an amphitheater, and the Garden of Music for events. A 3 km cycle path is available, along with the Nautical Club of Thessaloniki. The Thessaloniki Concert Hall, inaugurated in 2000, is inspired by Byzantine architecture and hosts various performances and conferences. It includes a main hall for 1464 attendees and a neighboring building with additional facilities. The Depot Area, named after historic tram depot buildings, retains traces of its older atmosphere. The Allatini Mills and the church of Saints Cyril and Methodius are also significant sites in the area.', "The Historic Centre features archaeological sites from the late Roman period, including shops from the 1st to 13th century and the underground Museum of the Roman Forum. A restored Odeon from the 2nd-4th century AD is now used for cultural events, alongside a mint and archive office. A round bathhouse dating back to the 1st century BC was also discovered, along with various artifacts like mosaics, sculptures, and coins. The forum is notable for the 'Enchanted Ones,' a two-storeyed colonnaded archway with surviving Corinthian columns, which were relocated to the Louvre in 1864. Bit-Pazar, a vibrant market area with antique shops and restaurants, was built in the 1930s and has become popular among students. Nearby, the Jewish Monastirioton Synagogue is the only one to survive World War II. The Experimental School, designed by architect D. Pikionis, was constructed from 1936 to 1938.", "The phrase 'Follow Greece Everywhere' suggests a strong interest or commitment to exploring and engaging with Greek culture, history, and lifestyle in various contexts.", "Thessaloniki has a rich history marked by the settlement of various communities, particularly from the Iberian Peninsula, and a period of harmony among ethnic groups from the 16th to 18th centuries. The city evolved into a significant trade center by the 18th century and became more cosmopolitan with railway connections established in the late 19th century. Major events include a devastating fire in 1890, the Greek army's seizure of the city in 1912 after five centuries of Ottoman rule, and a significant fire in 1917 that led to extensive rebuilding. The city faced challenges during the Asia Minor Catastrophe in 1922-1923, receiving many Greek refugees. The German occupation in 1943 resulted in the tragic loss of a large portion of the Jewish population. Thessaloniki experienced a severe earthquake in 1978, and later, in 1997 and 2014, it was recognized as the European Capital of Culture and the European Youth Capital, respectively.", 'The Macedonian Museum of Contemporary Art features a permanent collection of 1,800 works by notable Greek and foreign artists and has hosted over 100 exhibitions. The museum also has a library with over 2,500 specialized titles. The Teloglion Foundation of Art, established in 1972, houses a significant collection including Hellenistic statuettes and works by renowned 19th and 20th-century artists, along with hosting temporary exhibitions and educational programs. The Municipal Gallery displays over 1,000 artworks, focusing on Thessalonian artists from 1898 to 1967, and is part of the cultural offerings in Thessaloniki, which also includes the Society for Macedonian Studies and the Thessaloniki Cinema Museum.', 'The text describes various historical sites, including the Sanctuary of Isis, which is half-sunk in water and dedicated to the Egyptian goddess. It also mentions the Sanctuary of Olympian Zeus, completed in the Hellenistic period, featuring a large altar and Roman theatre. The Hellenistic Theatre, built in the 3rd century BC, hosts modern events today. The Sanctuary of Asklipios, active until the 3rd century AD, is noted for a statue of the goddess Hygeia. Additionally, the Cemetery Basilica from the 5th century is described, along with fortified walls originally constructed by Cassander, which have been reconstructed over time.', 'The historic centre features a museum with exhibits of ancient human skulls, including those from the Axios river and Petralona Cave. Notable sites include the Observatory, built in 1954, and Agiou Dimitriou Street, one of the oldest roads in the city, surrounded by Interwar Period architecture. The area has seen an influx of Eastern European emigrants who have opened shops and restaurants, adding diversity. Key attractions include the Dioikitirio, a neoclassical building from 1891 that now houses the Ministry of Macedonia-Thrace, and the Agios Dimitrios church.', 'The text describes several historical sites in the historic center, including Yeni Hamam, built in 1531, which served as a bathing place until 1944-45. Alaca Imaret, constructed in 1484, features skilled masonry and is occasionally used for cultural events. The Profitis Ilias Church and Panagia Lagoudiani Church, a 14th-century Byzantine basilica, are also mentioned, with the latter honoring the Virgin Mary and Saint Demetrius. Additionally, the Ataturk Museum, located in the former residence of Kemal Ataturk, showcases his life and includes a café. Lastly, Kaftanzogleio Stadium is noted as the largest stadium in the city.', 'Epanomi is a picturesque town 25 km SE of Thessaloniki, known for its beautiful beaches and a wetland that hosts over 80 bird species. The Gerovassiliou Wine Museum, unique in northern Greece, is located nearby. Nea Michaniona, a major fishing center 32 km S of Thessaloniki, features the largest fleet of deep-sea fish boats in Greece and a vibrant seafront with cafés and tavernas. Angelochori, a small village near Nea Michaniona, offers stunning views of the Olympus massif and historical Ottoman architecture. The area is also recognized for its high-quality beaches, such as Tourbani and Angelochori, which have received Blue Flag awards.', 'This text provides essential information for visitors to Thessaloniki, Greece, including contact details for the Greek National Tourism Organisation (GNTO) and the Ministry of Foreign Affairs. It lists various Greek acronyms relevant to tourists, such as E.O.T. for the GNTO and K.T.E.L. for intercity bus services. The text mentions the use of 220V electric current in Greece and highlights free wireless internet access in public areas. It also details the operating hours and locations of post offices in the city. Emergency phone numbers for police, fire brigade, and medical services are provided, along with contact information for tourist information services.', "Thessaloniki boasts a rich culinary tradition influenced by Byzantine, Ottoman, and various European cuisines, shaped by its multicultural history. The city's gastronomy features traditional tavernas and restaurants that creatively blend local dishes with gourmet elements. Notable delicacies include gyro, souvlaki, patsa, and a variety of seafood dishes. Desserts play a significant role, with popular items like bougatsa, galaktompoureko, and syrupy pastries originating from Istanbul. Koulouri Thessalonikis, a sesame-covered bread, is a common snack sold by street vendors. In winter, locals enjoy salep, a unique hot beverage.", 'Thessaloniki is a city in Greece known for its rich history, vibrant culture, and significant role in the Byzantine Empire. It is the second-largest city in Greece and features a mix of ancient and modern architecture, including Roman ruins and Ottoman-era structures. The city is also famous for its festivals, culinary scene, and lively waterfront.', 'The text mentions Thessaloniki and its neighboring areas, but does not provide further details or context.', 'Thessaloniki offers various sports facilities, including an 18-hole golf course at Porto Carras Grand Resort and proximity to several ski centers. Notable ski centers include Seli, Elatochori, 3-5 Pigadia, Lailias, Vora, and Falakro, each with different elevations, runs, and amenities. Information for each ski center, including contact details and websites, is provided. Additional resources for tourists include websites for the Municipality of Thessaloniki, archaeological sites, and weather forecasts.', "The Thessaloniki State Symphony Orchestra, established in 1959, is one of Greece's premier orchestras, performing at the Thessaloniki Concert Hall. The city also offers summer open-air cinemas where films are screened with Greek subtitles. Thessaloniki has a rich sports tradition, hosting major events like the 2004 Olympic Games and various international competitions. Numerous sports facilities are available, including the Kaftanzogleio National Stadium and Poseidonio Sports Centre. The Megas Alexandros International Marathon occurs annually, starting in Ancient Pella and finishing in Thessaloniki. Information on local sports facilities and events can be obtained from the municipality's departments.", 'The text provides a comprehensive overview of Thessaloniki, detailing various church denominations, museums, cultural exhibitions, sports facilities, public transport options, and traditional markets. It lists notable churches such as the Orthodox Metropolitan Church and the Armenian Orthodox Church, alongside museums like the Archaeological Museum of Thessaloniki and the Jewish Museum. Cultural venues include the Thessaloniki International Trade Fair and several theaters. Sports facilities mentioned include the Alexandreio Sports Arena and various football grounds. Public transport options include a long-distance bus station and a new railway station, while traditional markets like Kapani and Modiano are also highlighted.', "This publication by the Greek National Tourism Organisation, supervised by Angela Varela and coordinated by Eleni Mitraki, features contributions from various professionals including journalist Yannis Ragos and translator Angeliki Christopoulou. It includes photo credits from multiple photographers and is designed by Zoe Tzomentzidou. The publication is not for sale and is available through the Greek National Tourism Organisation's website.", 'Asprovalta and Nea Vrasna beaches offer marine sports and beach volleyball facilities, with Asprovalta beach being 10 km long and awarded a Blue Flag. Stavros is the largest harbor in the area, while the villages of Vrasna and Ano Stavros feature traditional architecture. To reach these locations from Thessaloniki, take bus lines 83, 83M, or 83N to Lagkadas, or travel by coach or car towards Panorama and Kavala. Pikrolimni, located in the Kilkis region, is a shallow lake known for its healing mud with properties three times more concentrated than the Dead Sea. The first Mud-therapy Centre in the Balkans is in nearby Xylokeratia, offering various wellness facilities. Visitors can enjoy mud therapy by the lake in summer, and the center includes a physiotherapy clinic, hotel, restaurant, and sports fields. Pikrolimni is accessible by car or a daily bus from Thessaloniki.', 'The Palace of Galerius is an open-air archaeological museum in the historic center, constructed in the late 3rd to early 4th century. It is part of the Galerian Complex, which included significant structures like the Hippodrome and Rotunda. The palace served as a residence for emperors until its destruction in the 7th century and is a major monument of Late Antiquity. Key features include the Octagon, an audience hall with elaborate decoration; a colonnaded yard; a two-storeyed tank for water collection; a monumental Basilica used for official gatherings; and a bathhouse with various bathing facilities.', "Eptapyrgio, built in the 12th century on an older fortress, features ten towers and remnants of Early Christian walls. The structure underwent modifications by the Ottoman Turks in 1431 and later became a prison in 1890. In 1989, it was transformed into a monument for visitors. Nearby, Palaeologina's Gate, constructed in 1355, leads to Trigoniou Tower, built in the 16th century. This area, known for its breathtaking views, is a popular spot for both locals and tourists.", "Thessaloniki's Old Town, untouched by the 1917 fire, features a mix of Macedonian and Ottoman architecture. It became populated in the mid-15th century when the Ottomans settled there due to its favorable climate and strategic location. The area retains its original town planning with narrow alleys and squares, attracting artists and students in recent years. Architectural styles include neoclassical and eclectic motifs, particularly in residences of the Dönmeh. Despite modern developments, the Old Town has preserved much of its historical character.", 'The 6th walk along NEA PARALIA – VASILISSIS OLGAS AVENUE showcases a busy street with impressive late 19th to early 20th-century buildings. Notable sites include Allatini Villa, built in 1898, which served various purposes over the years, including housing the University of Thessaloniki and a military hospital. Casa Bianca, constructed in 1912, features eclectic and art nouveau elements and now hosts a branch of the Municipal Art Gallery. The Nehama Villa, built in 1907, is another significant structure on the avenue. Lastly, the Mordoch Villa, established in 1905, has a rich history, including use as military barracks and a polyclinic, and currently houses the Municipal Art Gallery.', "The Historic Centre, built in 1866 by Sultan Hamid, was originally outside the east walls and restored in 1977 after modifications during the Interwar Period. Aristotle University of Thessaloniki (AUTH) is Greece's first university campus, established on the site of an old Jewish cemetery, with construction starting in 1938 and resuming in the 1950s. The campus features modern architecture by prominent Greek architects and accommodates over 100,000 students, making it the largest in Greece. Notable sites include the Old Building of the Faculty of Philosophy, constructed in 1887, and various museums showcasing ancient sculptures and Byzantine art.", "The Yeni Camii, built in 1902 by architect V. Poselli, served as a mosque for converted Jews and later housed the city's Archaeological Museum. It now functions as a municipal exhibition area with a collection of Roman and Early Christian sculptures. The Hatzimisef Villa, located on Vas. Olgas Ave., was the town's first high school, while the Joseph Modiano villa nearby is currently uninhabited. A bust of King George I, assassinated in 1913, stands at the corner of Vas. Olgas Ave. and Agias Triadas St., crafted by K. Dimitriadis in 1915. The Ivan Hatzimisef Villa, built in 1897, now hosts cultural events and an organic food market. Additionally, the building at 34-36 Evzonon Street features classical, baroque, and renaissance architectural styles.", "Lake Koroneia, also known as Lake Agios Vasileios, has significantly decreased in size and depth due to climate conditions and water resource exploitation. Nea Apollonia, a historic village near Lake Volvi, features mineral springs with therapeutic properties and modern health facilities. Lake Volvi is Greece's second-largest natural lake and a Ramsar site, offering birdwatching and various water sports. The area around Volvi includes tourist attractions and communities like Megali Volvi, Mikri Volvi, and Rentina, which is known for its natural beauty and historical ruins.", "The text describes various historical and cultural sites in Thessaloniki, including the Greek Highschool built in 1893 and the Transfiguration of Christ Church, established in 1840 on the site of a 1543 chapel. The church features an icon screen depicting the Annunciation, with elements dating back to 1843 and 1943. It also mentions the Thessaloniki International Fair (TIF), inaugurated in 1926 and relocated in 1940, which has modern convention centers designed by notable Greek architects. Additionally, the Macedonian Museum of Contemporary Art, established in 1979, is highlighted as Greece's first modern art museum, showcasing modern sculptures and ancient artifacts.", "The historic centre of Thessaloniki features industrial architecture from the late 19th century, including six warehouses built in 1910, which were revamped in 1997 for cultural events. These warehouses now house various institutions such as the International Film Festival, the Thessaloniki Cinema Museum, and the Centre of Contemporary Art. The Customs House, built in 1910, serves as the city's passenger board station and showcases early 20th-century French architectural influence. The Ladadika area, spared from the 1917 fire, dates back to the 16th century and was known for its wholesale trade, particularly spices and olive oil. The street layout remains largely unchanged since the late 19th century, with many buildings constructed from industrial brick and wood.", "The Military Museum of the Balkan Wars, located in Gefyra village near Thessaloniki, showcases the area's history with rare relics and authentic furniture from the time of the Greek army's headquarters in 1912. Giannitsa, a modern town with a population of 35,000, features significant Ottoman monuments, including the mausoleum of Gazi Evrenos and the 14th-century hamam. The town is known for its cultural heritage and outdoor activities in nearby green areas. Notable sites include the clock tower and various mosques, reflecting the rich history of the region.", 'Thessaloniki offers a vibrant nightlife with clubs and venues, especially in the summer when many move to open-air locations. Popular areas include Kalamaria and Peraia. The city hosts numerous artistic events year-round, featuring venues like the Thessaloniki Concert Hall and various theaters. Cultural activities include the International Film Festival and the Thessaloniki Book Fair. The Thessaloniki Regency Casino operates 24/7, requiring guests to be 25 or older. Additionally, traditional products like koulouri and trigona Panoramatos are notable in the region.', 'The exhibition showcases Byzantine life, art, and culture from the early to post-Byzantine periods, organized by thematic categories. It includes sections on the Early Christian period, Middle Byzantine period, Late Byzantine period, and Post Byzantine period, each with specific rooms dedicated to various aspects of life and culture. The exhibition also features private collections, including the D. Papastratos Collection with religious art and the D. Oikonomopoulos Collection with a diverse range of artworks. The Jewish Museum of Thessaloniki is mentioned, highlighting its permanent exhibits related to Jewish history.', "The Archaeological Museum of Thessaloniki displays significant art and artifacts from Macedonia, spanning from prehistoric times to late antiquity. The exhibits are categorized into six sections, including the origins of towns, the evolution of Macedonia from the 7th century BC to late antiquity, and the historical significance of Thessaloniki. Notable displays include exceptional gold craftsmanship from cemeteries, a reconstruction of an archaic temple, and unique items like the Derveni papyrus. The museum highlights the region's rich cultural heritage and its transition through various historical periods.", "Thessaloniki hosts several cultural institutions, including museums and galleries showcasing Greek art. The collection features works by prominent Greek artists, Byzantine icons spanning five centuries, and Greek engravings. The Gallery of the Society for Macedonian Studies is the city's first visual arts museum, displaying 300 pieces from major 20th-century art movements. The Cultural Centre of Thessaloniki organizes exhibitions in collaboration with local agencies, featuring around 250 pieces of various art forms. The Thessaloniki Cinema Museum, established in 1997, highlights the history of Greek cinema through exhibits categorized into six timelines.", "The text describes various historical and cultural sites in Thessaloniki, including the Holy Twelve Apostles Church and the remnants of the city's west walls, particularly the Litaia Gate. It highlights the Pasha Hamam, an Ottoman bathhouse built in the 1520s, which was the last of its kind in the area until its closure in 1981. The west of the harbour area saw significant growth in the late 19th century due to the demolition of city walls and the development of industrial units, which have since been transformed into cultural and entertainment venues. Notable sites include the Vilka multi-purpose venue, formerly a textile factory, and the Mylos venue, popular for events. The Moni Lazariston complex houses the State Museum of Contemporary Art, showcasing the area's cultural evolution.", 'The text provides contact information and websites for various museums and cultural institutions in Thessaloniki, including the Thessaloniki Cinema Museum, Museum of Photography, Olympic Museum, and more. It lists their addresses, telephone numbers, and websites, facilitating access to cultural resources. Additionally, it mentions a collaboration among five museums in Thessaloniki aimed at promoting cultural activities and organizing exhibitions. This collaboration includes the Archaeological Museum, Museum of Byzantine Culture, State Museum of Contemporary Art, Macedonian Museum of Modern Art, and the Teloglion Foundation of Art.', 'The text describes various historical and architectural sites in Thessaloniki, including the Jewish Museum housed in a 1904 building, Venizelou Street known for its eclectic and art deco styles, and the Pazar (Yahudi) Hamami, a 16th-century bathhouse. It highlights the architectural significance of the Gategno-Florentin Building and the Chamber of Commerce & Industry, showcasing neoclassical design. The area is also noted for its vibrant marketplace, including an open-air flower market known as Louloudadika.', 'The text describes two significant Byzantine monuments in the city. The first is the Moni Latomou, an early cross-in-square domed church from the 5th or 6th century, notable for its ceiling mosaics depicting the Vision of Ezekiel and a minaret entrance from its later conversion to a mosque. The second is Moni Vlatadon, the only active Byzantine monastery in the city, founded in the 14th century, featuring a unique church structure and significant murals from the 14th and 17th centuries. It also has a large garden with views of the city and additional facilities like a library and a bookstore.', 'Thessaloniki is a city in Greece known for its rich history, vibrant culture, and significant role in the Byzantine Empire.', 'The text describes the historical development of the area known as Nea Paralia in Thessaloniki, which began to grow in the late 19th century after the demolition of city walls and the introduction of tramways. Initially named Exoches due to its rural character, it became a luxury residential area with diverse nationalities coexisting. However, from the 1930s, the area declined and transformed into a typical urban setting by the 1960s. Today, Nea Paralia stretches along Megalou Alexandrou Avenue and is popular for leisure activities, offering scenic views of the Thermaic Gulf and Mount Olympus, especially at sunset. Notable landmarks include the statue of Alexander the Great and the artistic installation of umbrellas by N. Zongolopoulos.', "Thessaloniki, an early center of Christianity, was significant during the Byzantine period, housing numerous Christian monuments and churches. These structures, built between the 4th and 15th centuries, have been recognized as UNESCO World Heritage Monuments since 1988. The Holy Twelve Apostles Church, one of the oldest, was constructed between 1310 and 1314 and served as the main church of a monastery. The church features murals and iconography depicting the life of the Holy Virgin. A tour of Thessaloniki's Byzantine monuments offers a unique experience, showcasing the city's rich historical and cultural heritage.", 'The text describes various notable locations in Ano Poli, Thessaloniki. Tsitsani Square features a bust of composer V. Tsitsanis and is surrounded by well-tended houses. Eptapyrgiou Street runs along the northern city walls, showcasing traditional buildings and the old Zihne Camii mosque. Moni Vlatadon is mentioned as a point of interest. Portara is one of the main gates of the northern city walls, adorned with ceramics and inscriptions. The Acropolis, specifically Eptapyrgio (Yedi Kule), is highlighted as a significant fortified area within the city walls. The area is popular among both residents and tourists.', 'The text provides information about various churches in Thessaloniki, including their addresses and contact numbers. It also highlights cultural events such as Demetria, an autumn festival featuring theatrical and musical performances, and the Thessaloniki International Film Festival, which has been held since 1960 and showcases films from various sections. Additionally, it mentions the Thessaloniki International Fair (T.I.F.), a significant trade fair in the Balkans that has been taking place since 1926, presenting Greek industry and entrepreneurship. Contact information for cultural offices and event organizations is also included.', "Thessaloniki was founded in 315 BC by Cassander, named after his wife, and became a significant city under Roman control by 168 BC. It served as the capital of the Roman province of Macedonia by 148 BC and was connected to the wider world through the Via Egnatia around 130 BC. The city was declared a 'free town' in 42 BC and hosted Apostle Paul's visits. In the late 3rd to early 4th century AD, it became the seat of the eastern Roman Empire under Galerius. The city faced various raids but was protected by its walls. It experienced a golden age from 1300 to 1430, marked by cultural and economic growth. Thessaloniki changed hands multiple times, falling to the Venetians in 1423 and the Ottoman Turks in 1430, while also having a significant Jewish population in the 15th century."]
reference: The historical and cultural significance of various landmarks and areas in Thessaloniki, such as the Historic Centre, traditional restaurants, and notable museums, is highlighted through their architectural features, historical transformations, and the vibrant atmosphere they contribute to the city.

buses to N. Michaniona or

If you go by car, follow Ethnikis

6 	EPANOMI
This picturesque town 
(population: 7,500) is situated 
25 km SE of Thessaloniki. In 
the vicinity there are beautiful 
beaches, namely Ktima 
Karagiozi, Ormos, Palioura, 
Ageladariko, Mesimeri and 
Potamos; you will also see a 
half-sunken wreck of a small 
merchant vessel lying there 
since 1967. Tsairi (4 km S 
of Epanomi) is the location 
of a wetland, a refuge for 
over 80 species of birds. 
Gerovassiliou Wine Museum 
is situated 2 km N. and is the 
only one of its kind in northern 
Greece (for the museum see 
p. 80).
How to get there. Take 
the buses nos. 70 and 70A 
from the Railway Station 
Stop during July and August. 
Throughout the year board 
any one of 69A, 69B, 69E, 
69K, 69N, 69R, 69T or 69X 
buses at A.S. IKEA station. 
If you travel by car, head for 
the airport and then follow 
Michanionas, Miaouli and 
Epanomis country roads.
7 	NEA MICHANIONA
A major fishing centre (32 
km S of Thessaloniki) with 
the largest fleet of deep sea 
fish boats in Greece! Once a 
refugee settlement, it is now a 
steadily growing area. The fish 
pier building by the picturesque 
harbour gets crowded especially 
during the early morning hours. 
Τhe seafront road is lined with 
café-bars and tavernas. Popular 
beaches in this area such as 
Tourbani and Angelochori have 
been awarded the Blue Flag  
for their beach quality.
MUST SEE:
7.1  Angelochori.
This small village lies 4 km  
N. of Nea Michaniona. 
Cape Megalo Emvolo (or 
Megalo Karampournou) 
affords a wonderful view of 
the Olympus massif. It is 
worth noticing the particular 
architectural structure of the 
remaining parts of an ottoman 
stronghold, built there in 1884 
by German civil engineers; 
there is also a lighthouse 
reaching a height of 10.50 m.  
75. Nea 
Michaniona 
is one of 
the greatest 
fisheries in 
Greece.
76. Peraia 
beach.
77. View of 
the seafront at 
Neoi Epivates.
78. You will 
find modern, 
well-equipped 
water sports 
facilities in 
the area from 
Peraia to 
Epanomi.
75']
reference: The Gerovassiliou Wine Museum is unique in northern Greece as it is the only one of its kind in the region.

user_input: What architectural features distinguish Bey Hamami as the largest Ottoman bath house in the country?
reference_contexts:
['4th walk: 
HISTORIC CENTRE (3)
1.3  Plateia Dikastirion 
[Court house square]. 
A spacious green square 
situated towards the end 
of Aristotelous Street. 
The Hébrard plans placed 
construction of the Court 
House as well as of other  
state buildings on this location 
(to create a civic centre);  
in 1966, however, excavations 
on the spot revealed the 
Ancient Roman Forum and  
the process was halted. In  
the centre of the square stands 
the imposing bust of Eleftherios 
Venizelos (1977, G. Pappas), 
who remained a prime minister 
of Greece for more than 12 
years during the period 1910 – 
1932. There are small copper 
workshops in the adjacent 
Chalkeon and Kleisouras 
Streets, and their business has 
been an ongoing tradition since 
the byzantine period.
1.4  Panagia [Virgin Mary] 
Chalkeon.
(see p. 9)
1.5  Bey Hamami.
It lies on the SE side of  
Plateia Dikastirion. This impressive 
edifice was built in 1444 and  
it is the country’s largest 
ottoman bath house, a multi-
domed construction with 
separate rooms for males and 
females, structured along two 
parallel ways. It is divided in 
three sections (cold, tepid 
and hot areas) and there is 
also a vaulted tank for heating 
water. It is widely known as the 
Paradise Baths and it went by 
that name until 1968. Right next 
to it there is a roman platform 
that is indicative of the ground 
level 2000 years ago.
1.6  Roman (Ancient) Forum
During the roman period, 
this 2-hectare area used to be 
the social and religious centre 
of the city. Construction was 
completed in two phases  
(in the mid-2nd and mid-  
3rd centuries AD) and it was 
gradually abandoned after the 
7th century. The NW section 
of the archaeological site is 
covered by a large rectangular 
square [Α] with traces of 
marble paving. In the S section 
of the square lies the largest 
part of the double underground 
Cryptoporticus [covered 
passageway] [Β] which was 
most probably used as a public 
storehouse. On one of its walls 
a valuable early Christian mural 
was uncovered and this shows

WITH CHILDREN
Thessaloniki’s relatively 
small size - for a city –

Thessaloniki Wines. 
Macedonia has a long 
tradition on wine-making, 
as the district can boast 
some of the most renowned 
Greek vineyards. In the area 
surrounding the town, a wide 
range of varieties are grown 
such as Roditis, Asyrtiko, 
Malagouzia, Sauvignon 
Blanc, Chardonnay, Voignier, 
Syrah, Merlot, Grenache 
Rouge, Limnio, Mavroudi, 
Mavrotragano, Xinomavro, 
Cabernet Sauvignon, Athiri and 
Malvasia. The Wine Producers

Greece Vineyards, under the

countryside activities, as

you visit the impressive 
Gerovassiliou Wine Museum

user_input: What are the healing properties of the mud found in Pikrolimni?
reference_contexts:
['How to get there. From 
Thessaloniki, take the 83, 
83M or 83N bus line to reach 
Lagkadas. For the other areas, 
travel by coach. If you go 
by car, head for Panorama, 
Chortiatis and Agios Vasileios 
(to reach Lake Koroneia) 
and from that point go east 
towards Kavala (to visit Lake 
Volvi and the Strymonian gulf).
6 	PIKROLIMNI 
It is located in the 
neighbouring Kilkis regional 
unit, to the south. It is a 
shallow lake (covering a 
450-hectare area) and in 
the lake floor mud there are 
chemical combinations such 
as sulphides and nitric salts 
with healing and cosmetic 
properties known across the 
country - the concentration 
is three times higher than 
that in the Dead Sea. In the 
neighbouring Xylokeratia 
village you can visit the first 
Mud-therapy (Spa) Centre 
in the Balkans. There are 
swimming pools for men 
and women, 10 personal 
hydromassage areas where 
mineral spring water is used, 
saunas, a gym and areas 
for mud treatment. In the 
summer, visitors can enjoy 
a special mud therapy by 
the lake shore which gets 
usually dried up during the 
warmest season of the year. 
In the grounds you will find 
a physiotherapy centre and 
a medical clinic, a hotel, a 
restaurant, a bar, basketball 
and football fields.
How to get there. 
Pikrolimni is located 23 
km N of Thessaloniki. If 
you travel by car, follow the 
signs to Kilkis and after that, 
from Galliko village head 
for Xylokeratia (Pikrolimni). 
Alternatively there is a bus 
from Dimokratias square 
(Vardari) leaving daily at 9 am, 
which will take you to the Mud 
Therapy Centre for free.
DAY EXCURSIONS
114']
reference: The mud found in Pikrolimni has healing and cosmetic properties due to its chemical combinations such as sulphides and nitric salts, with a concentration three times higher than that in the Dead Sea.

user_input: What some notable features of MUSEUM AREA in historic centre?
reference_contexts:
['3rd walk: 
HISTORIC CENTRE (2)
MUSEUM AREA
a café as well as the eclectic-
style (military) building at the 
corner of Vas. Georgiou and 
Kaftanzoglou Streets, now 
housing the local branch  
of the Greek Scouts.
2 	NIKIS AVENUE
(see p. 16)
3 	SHOPPING STREETS
In the area including 
Proxenou Koromila and 
Mitropoleos roads and the 
adjacent streets such as 
Palaion Patron Germanou-
Vogatsikou, Chrysostomou 
Smyrnis, Mitropolitou Iosif, 
Lassani, Agias Sofias, Karolou 
Dil (lined with remarkable 
buildings of the interwar 
period) and Tsimiski street, 
you will find some of the 
most expensive shops (selling 
clothes, shoes, jewellery, 
furniture, accessories etc) as 
well as a number of the most 
well-known shopping malls 
in the city. You will also find 
haute couture boutiques by 
Greek and foreign designers 
and several art galleries. 
Thessalonians visit the area  
for their shopping as they 
go out for a coffee, a meal 
or a drink in the numerous 
hangouts lining the streets.
4 	\x07MUSEUM FOR 
THE MACEDONIAN 
STRUGGLE
The building is among the 
very few purely neo-classical 
ones in town; it was built 
in the years 1890-1893 to 
plans by Ernst Ziller after the 
1890 fire. Until 1912 this 
building housed the Greek 
General Consulate and during 
the period 1923-1978 it 
provided the space for the 
state elementary schools. After 
that, the facility has housed 
collections of the Museum 
(see p. 74). Right next to it, 
you will see the metropolitan 
church of Agios Gregorios 
Palamas (1914, plans by  
E. Ziller and Xen. Paionidis); 
it is classified as a Byzantine 
domed octagon type with neo-
Romanic and neo-classical 
elements. Behind the church, 
at the corner of Vogatsikou 
and Mitropoleos streets, you 
will see the Ecclesiastical 
Museum of the Metropolitan 
Church of Thessaloniki, 
where a major collection of 
24
']
reference: Notable features of the MUSEUM AREA in the historic centre include an eclectic-style military building housing the local branch of the Greek Scouts, the Museum for the Macedonian Struggle which is a neo-classical building, and the metropolitan church of Agios Gregorios Palamas with its Byzantine domed octagon type architecture.

user_input: What significance does the gold larnax hold in the context of King Philip II's burial and the artifacts found in his tomb?
reference_contexts:
['DAY EXCURSIONS
armosphere is particularly 
emotive as the place is dark 
with selective lighting on the 
exhibits. Past the entrance 
there are funerary steles,  
finds from tombs of locals  
of that time and the ruins  
of a 3rd c. BC tomb (tomb 
IV), consisting of parts of 
walls and pillars as well as the 
façade’s superstructure. Next 
is the Memorial, a monument 
dedicated to the memory of 
distinguished persons and  
after that there is a cist tomb 
(tomb I of Persephone) that 
belonged to one of the wives 
of Philip II. In the next section 
lie the tomb of King Philip 
II with exquisite murals and 
friezes on display as well as 
arms and his suit of armour 
decorated with gold; the 
remains of the funeral pyre;  
the gold larnax that weighs  
11 kg and contained the bones 
and the golden oak wreath 
of the dead king, decorated 
with the macedonian star (or 
Vergina Sun); the gold larnax 
of the royal wife; the cloth 
embroidered with gold threads 
which covered the two larnakes 
(chest-shaped coffins); and 
the two gold and ivory beds. 
The last part consists of 
what is believed to have 
been the tomb of Alexander 
IV, son of Alexander the 
Great and Roxanne, who was 
assassinated by Cassander in 
310 BC; a silver urn containing 
the bones of the dead person, 
framed with the ivory relief 
motifs of the funeral bed. 
In a separate room, visitors 
can watch a video where M. 
Andronikos takes them on a 
tour of the monuments. Other 
excavations in the wider area 
of the Aiges necropolis have 
unearthed archaic tombs, pit 
and cist tombs (6th and 5th c. 
BC), as well as temple-shaped 
macedonian tombs one of 
which apparently belonged  
to Queen Eurydice, the mother  
of King Philip II
Palace. It covers a 12,500 
m2 area and it used to be 
the largest and the most 
important construction (next 
to Parthenon, Athens) of the 
Hellenic Classical Antiquity. 
This two-storeyed edifice 
is presumed to be the work 
of Pytheos who was the 
architect of the Mausoleum 
of Halicarnassos [modern-day 
Bodrum, Turkey], one of the 7 
wonders of the ancient world. 
The palace’s architectural style 
is considered avant-garde for 
that time and it was built of 
limestone during the 2nd half 
of the 4th c. BC on a plateau; 
101, 102 & 
103.  
The Royal 
Tombs of 
Vergina: (left) 
the golden 
larnax of 
Meda, wife of 
King Philip II; 
(middle) the 
King’s burial 
place; (right) 
the urn bearing 
the gold wreath 
of Alexander IV.
101']
reference: The gold larnax holds significant importance in King Philip II's burial as it contained his bones and a golden oak wreath, symbolizing his royal status, and is a key artifact among the exquisite items found in his tomb.

user_input: What criteria led to Mount Athos being designated as a UNESCO World Heritage site?
reference_contexts:
['DAY EXCURSIONS
a day trip (it’s only a short 
distance from the city) or 
for a longer one; quite a few 
own country houses there. In 
the Athos peninsula amidst 
a beautiful and pristine 
natural environment lies the 
globally known monastic 
state of Mount Athos which 
encompasses 20 -presently 
inhabited- monasteries 
(10th – 14th c.), sketes [small 
monastic settlements] and 
cells for monks. UNESCO has 
included the ‘Holy Mount’ in its 
World Heritage Monument List 
in 1988, on grounds of the 
outstanding architecture and 
the priceless cultural treasures 
of the monastic community.
How to get there. 
Petralona Cave is situated  
53 km SE of Thessaloniki. Take 
the coach to Halkidiki, get 
off at Nea Kallikrateia Village 
stop and then take a taxi to 
the cave (approx. a 10-km 
journey). If you travel by car, 
go along the Thessaloniki-
Halkidiki national road and  
then follow the signs to 
Petralona village and the cave.
5 	LAKES AREA
Northeast of Thessaloniki, in 
the direction of Strymonas 
(also Strymonian) gulf 
stretches a 200,000 hectare-
area around Lakes Koroneia 
and Volvi; the place is a 
National Park. It is a rare 
group of ecosystems with wet 
forests and meadows, rivers 
and shrubland, and the ideal 
place for outdoor activities 
(horse-riding, mountain biking, 
birdwatching, agritourism 
and so on); the Agency for 
the Management of Lakes 
Koroneia and Volvi (www.
foreaskv.gr) runs tours in 
the area. Make sure you try 
some of the local delicacies, 
including lake fish dishes.
MUST SEE:
5.1  Lagadas.
This picturesque town 
is situated 20 km NE of 
Thessaloniki and has been 
known for keeping the custom 
of fire-walking (anastenaria) 
on May 21st. The ultra modern 
Spa facilities of the area also 
include two Byzantine bathtubs 
(10th and 15th c.) and they 
are located two km E amid 
lush greenery. The sulphur 
springs (water temperature: 
39.2ο C) are recommended 
for treating neuropathy, 
rheumatism, arthritis, skin and 
gynaecological diseases.
111']
reference: Mount Athos was designated as a UNESCO World Heritage site in 1988 due to its outstanding architecture and priceless cultural treasures of the monastic community.

user_input: What activities can visitors enjoy at the mountain refuge located on Mt Chortiatis?
reference_contexts:
['SUBURBS AND CITY OUTSKIRTS
3.1  Chortiatis.
Named after the mountain, 
this small suburb on Mt 
Chortiatis (elev.: 1,201 m.), 
stretches approx. 10 km NE  
of Panorama. Since the Roman 
times, Thessaloniki’s water 
supply came from this place 
via Vlatadon Monastery (see 
p. 44); this is why you will 
see fragments of a Byzantine 
aqueduct at the suburb’s 
border. The mountain is covered 
with chestnut, oak, beech and 
fir trees, there is a mountain 
refuge (Kissos location, elev. 
1,201 m.) and it is the ideal 
place for hiking (there are 32 
charted paths), for mountain 
biking and off-roading.
How to get there. Board 
the 58 bus on Egnatia Street 
and get off at Dimarchio 
[Town Hall], Astynomia [Police 
Station] or at Platanakia stop.
4 	THERMI
This suburb is located a bit 
further away from town (15 km 
SE of the city centre) and more 
or less still keeps a countryside 
air about it. On-site excavations 
have shown that this was the 
location of the harbour of 
ancient Thermi, a major one  
in antiquity. The place was also 
known for its hot springs – 
thermae – hence the name  
of the gulf (Thermaikos). During 
the Byzantine and Ottoman 
period it was known as Sedes; 
in modern times, refugees 
inhabited the area in the early 
20th c.
']
reference: Visitors at the mountain refuge on Mt Chortiatis can enjoy activities such as hiking on 32 charted paths, mountain biking, and off-roading.

user_input: What architectural features define a cross-in-square domed church, as exemplified by the Moni Latomou?
reference_contexts:
['1st walk: 
UNESCO BYZANTINE MONUMENTS
During the Ottoman period it 
was named Kule Hamam and 
was divided in two (male and 
female section).
12 	\x07HOSIOS DAVID  
(MONI LATOMOU)
Moni Latomou [Latomou 
Monastery] has a huge 
archaeological and historical 
value, since it is an early type 
of a cross-in-square domed 
church. Its construction dates 
back to the 5th or 6th c. and 
it is believed to have been 
built by Theodora, daughter 
of the Byzantine emperor 
Maximilianus, who had been 
baptised a Christian. The 
monastery was dedicated to 
Hosios David [Saint David] in 
1921. Especially noteworthy 
are the mosaic depictions 
on the ceiling which show 
the Vision of Ezekiel and 
are contemporary to the 
construction of the monastery; 
the later ones of the 12th, 13th 
and 14th c. are also great art 
specimens of the Komnenian 
period. There is a surviving 
minaret entrance built in the 
16th c. when the church was 
converted into a mosque. The 
small picturesque yard offers 
an unobstructed view of the 
city and the Thermaic gulf.
13 	MONI VLATADON
It is the only Byzantine 
monastery in the city with 
an active community. It was 
founded in the 14th c. by the 
monks Vlatis (or Vlateus) 
brothers and was dedicated to 
Pantocrator Christos [Almighty 
Christ]. Celebrations take 
place on the Transfiguration 
of Christ feast day. Its main 
church [katholikon] is of the 
inscribed cross-in-square type 
but the dome rests on the 
walls and on two piers instead 
of columns. It is surrounded 
by a portico and there are two 
chapels. Murals were painted 
during 1360 – 1380 and the 
17th c. iconostasis is particularly 
noteworthy. It is surrounded 
by a large garden offering a 
wonderful view of the city and 
there is also a small peacock 
farm; in the grounds you will 
also find the newer buildings 
of Misirogleios Library, the 
Patriarchal Foundation for 
Theological Studies (1968),  
a space provided for the study of 
pictorial manuscripts from Mount 
Athos, a bookstore and a shop.
8
']
reference: A cross-in-square domed church, as exemplified by the Moni Latomou, is defined by its early construction dating back to the 5th or 6th century, featuring a dome that rests on the walls and is surrounded by an inscribed cross layout.

user_input: What architectural significance does the Aristotle University of Thessaloniki hold in Greece?
reference_contexts:
['4th walk: 
HISTORIC CENTRE (3)
at the centre of this transport 
hub. It was built in 1866  
by Sultan Hamid as a gift  
to the city and it was at that 
time situated outside the 
east walls (Cassander’s Gate). 
During the Interwar Period a 
large part of it was removed 
to make Egnatia Street wider; 
it was restored to its original 
shape in 1977.
2 	\x07ARISTOTLE 
UNIVERSITY OF 
THESSALONIKI (AUTH).
This is the first University 
Campus in Greece (covering 
a 50 hectare area) to have 
been built following complete 
architectural plans. It was 
planned to be constructed 
on the location of the old 
Jewish cemetery (see p. 61), 
according to the Hébrard 
committee plan; construction 
finally began in 1938, yet the 
works were interrupted during 
the war and resumed in the 
1950s. Since then, several 
buildings were erected on 
these grounds by leading Greek 
architects following mostly the 
Modernist design, such as the 
main Administration Buildings 
as well as those built for the 
Schools of Chemistry, Law, 
Theology and Education and 
the two buildings of the Main 
Library; all the above form  
a major ensemble of modern 
architecture. Today there 
are over 100,000 enrolled 
students (the biggest campus 
in Greece) who add verve  
and youthfulness to the city.
MUST SEE:
2.1  Old Building of the 
Faculty of Philosophy.
This impressive construction 
took place in 1887, designed 
by V. Poselli. In 1908, two 
two-storey side wings were 
added and in 1927 the then 
newly established University 
of Thessaloniki (1925) was 
moved here from its former 
seat in Allatini Villa (see p. 
54). A number of schools of 
the Faculty of Philosophy of 
the AUTh are housed in this 
building today.
2.2  Museums of the A.U.Th.
Plaster casts of ancient 
sculptures and copies of 
miniature art, murals dating 
from the Minoan up to the 
Byzantine period as well as 
Byzantine icons are all on 
display at the Cast Museum. 
The Geology & Paleontology 
37.  
The grand 
building of 
the Faculty of 
Philosophy, 
Aristotle 
University of 
Thessaloniki.
38.  
View of the 
Aristotle 
University of 
Thessaloniki 
campus area.
39.  
The neoclassical 
building of 
Dioikitirio 
[Government 
House].
38
37']
reference: The Aristotle University of Thessaloniki holds architectural significance as the first university campus in Greece built following complete architectural plans, featuring a major ensemble of modern architecture designed by leading Greek architects.

user_input: What historical significance does the Thessaloniki History Centre hold in relation to the city's past?

['3rd walk:

user_input: What historical significance does Ethnikis Amynis Street hold in relation to the development of Thessaloniki?
reference_contexts:
['3rd walk: 
HISTORIC CENTRE (2)
MUSEUM AREA
various names; in the 19th 
c. it was called Tower of the 
Janissaries or Blood Tower  
as it served as jail for 
prisoners on death row 
whose life was eventually 
taken by the Janissaries on 
the ramparts. In 1890 it was 
painted white thus acquiring 
its current name. A particularly 
interesting exhibition is held 
in the Tower on the history 
of Thessaloniki (see p. 73); 
from the top of the Tower 
you can enjoy the panoramic 
view. The small square around 
the monument is one of the 
hotspots in town; this is where 
small boat bars leave for a 
short run within the Thermaic 
Gulf, serving coffee or a drink. 
Opposite lies the Park of the 
White Tower where you will 
find the open air Municipal 
Garden Theatre,  
a bar, a playground and  
a skate spot.
1.2  Royal [Vasiliko] 
Theatre.
It was built in 1940, got 
renovated in 1996, and it has 
a seating capacity of 800. 
This is one of the winter halls 
(Melina Merkouri Hall) of the 
State Theatre of Northern 
Greece (S.T.N.G., see p. 110). 
1.3  Ethnikis Amynis 
Street.
It leads from the White 
Tower to Syntrivaniou Square 
(see p. 37) and to Agiou 
Dimitriou Street (see p. 39). 
It was laid out after the 1889 
demolition of the eastern 
city walls (a section of its 
Byzantine ramparts still stands 
on Filikis Etaireias Street which 
runs parallel to Ethnikis Amynis 
Street. Until 1912 it was called 
Hamidiye Boulevard, in honour 
of the Sultan Abdul Hamid 
II, as all the buildings along 
the street were his property. 
Today, this is the location of 
the Theatre of the Society for 
Macedonian Studies (1962, 
V. Kassandras) housing the 
State Theatre of Northern 
Greece (S.T.N.G.) as well as  
the Gallery of the S.M.S. (see p. 
77), and the adjacent Building 
A’ of the S.M.S. (1951, A. 
Nikolopoulos), the Hellenic 
Army Club (1953, P. Mylonas) 
and Alexandros cinema. The 
small Tsirogiannis Park is 
situated nearby and around 
it you will find some popular 
cafés and bars. 
1.4  Diagonios.
This typical downtown 
22
']
reference: Ethnikis Amynis Street holds historical significance as it was laid out after the 1889 demolition of the eastern city walls and was previously known as Hamidiye Boulevard until 1912, reflecting its connection to Sultan Abdul Hamid II and the properties along the street.

7.1  Angelochori.
This small village lies 4 km

worth noticing the particular

there is also a lighthouse 
reaching a height of 10.50 m.

is one of

fisheries in

beach.
77. View of 
the seafront at 
Neoi Epivates.
78. You will 
find modern, 
well-equipped 
water sports 
facilities in 
the area from 
Peraia to 
Epanomi.
75
']
reference: The Ottoman stronghold in Angelochori, built in 1884 by German civil engineers, holds historical significance due to its architectural structure, which includes a lighthouse reaching a height of 10.50 m.

Irakleiou St. (until 8.30 pm). Other post offices in the town centre are at 98, Agiou Dimitriou St. (University campus); and at the Railway Station (until 2.30 pm).
